message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and physical findings suggest chronic venous insufficiency. Duplex ultrasonography is the standard diagnostic test for deep vein thrombosis and chronic venous insufficiency. CT scan and nerve conduction studies are not helpful in this case. D-dimer assay is a screening test for deep vein thrombosis, but a negative result does not rule out the disease in this case due to the patient’s history of previous deep vein thrombosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and physical examination suggest chronic venous insufficiency. Duplex ultrasonography is the best diagnostic option for evaluating venous disease, including deep vein thrombosis, venous reflux, and valvular insufficiency. CT scan with contrast is not preferred in this case. Nerve conduction studies are used to evaluate peripheral neuropathy, and D-dimer assay is not specific enough for diagnosing chronic venous insufficiency.

Duplex ultrasonography is the most appropriate and accurate test to diagnose chronic venous insufficiency. Computerized tomography scan with contrast is not necessary for this condition, nerve conduction studies are used for nerve disorders, and D-dimer assay is useful for detecting acute deep vein thrombosis.

A D-dimer assay is used to test for the presence of a blood clot, but the patient’s history of deep vein thrombosis confirms that she has already had a clot.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, such as pain, swelling, and discoloration suggest deep vein thrombosis, and duplex ultrasonography is the recommended imaging modality for diagnosing deep vein thrombosis. CT scan is not a first-line test for deep vein thrombosis. Nerve conduction studies are not helpful in diagnosing deep vein thrombosis. D-dimer assay is a useful test when the pretest probability is low, but in this case, the patient has a high pretest probability due to a history of deep vein thrombosis.
